awd_titl_txt: WiFiUS: Millimeter Wave-Based Wearable Networks in High-End IoT Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Wearable electronic devices for advanced applications like augmented or virtual reality typically generate large amounts of data. Using wireless links to deliver such data avoids the need for cumbersome cables, yet conventional wireless technologies do not support the gigabits per second throughput envisioned by these emerging applications. Millimeter wave communication is one solution to provide wearable electronic devices with higher data rates and lower latency. This research is aimed at providing a rigorous and systematic design of the key aspects of a millimeter wave wearable network. The emphasis is placed on designing important aspects of the system that will permit operation in crowded areas with many people using wearable devices. Broader impacts include teaching, mentoring, participation of underrepresented groups, community outreach through demonstrations and videos, and technology transfer through collaborations with industry partners.

This research project addresses the fundamentals of communication in millimeter wave wearable links at the physical layer and medium access control layers. On the theoretical side, this project develops new mathematical tools for estimating millimeter wave channels and devises new algorithms for communicating in millimeter wave multiple antenna channels incorporating array constraints. It also creates new protocols, which are designed from the ground up to include multiple antenna capabilities not found in existing millimeter wave medium access control protocol work. On the practical side, this project creates channel models that incorporate array geometry, orientation, and blockage effects tailored to the wearable setting. It also implements key aspects of the algorithms in a testbed to validate the theoretical hypotheses and provide refinements to models. Outcomes of this research include rapidly re-configurable and robust high bandwidth millimeter wave communication links for wearable devices.

por.por_cntn:
Millimeter wave (mmWave) bands can support Gbps data rates if the link between the transmitting and receiving ends is configured properly. The link configuration, however, is challenging due to hardware constraints and impairments in mmWave systems. This project develops new tools and techniques forrapid and efficient link configuration in mmWave systems. 

Frequency synchronization, channel estimation, and beam alignment, are some important and difficult link configuration steps in mmWave systems. Existing techniques that solve these problems in lower frequency systems may not be applicable at mmWave, due to the differences in channel properties and the hardware. In this project, we developed new link configuration solutions that exploit channel structure under strict hardware constraints. We also designed new waveforms and low complexity algorithms that achieve robustness to hardware non-idealities. Our solutions, when applied to mmWave systems, can enable high speed links with lower training overhead than many existing solutions. The mathematical ideas underlying our methods can be applied to other disciplines such as radar, computational imaging, spectroscopy, and magnetic resonance imaging.

In terms of intellectual merit, select results are summarized as follows. 

  • Message passing-based algorithms for mmWave link configuration. In this research direction, we developed a joint frequency synchronization and wideband channel estimation algorithm for mmWave systems. We also proposed a framework and a message passing-based algorithm for beam alignment in near field systems.  Our solutions are based on the theories of compressed sensing, bilinear system identification, and generalized approximate message passing. 
  • Sequence design for rapid and robust beam alignment. We designed new sequences and arrays for low complexity beam alignment. Our design is based on perfect binary arrays and can be implemented in phased arrays of any resolution. We also proposed a novel construction of compressed sensing matrices for mmWave beam alignment robust to frequency synchronization errors. The proposed construction can be used in applications like radar, spectroscopy, and imaging, to achieve low complexity signal reconstruction that is robust to radio frequency impairments.
  • Dictionary learning aided algorithms for sparse channel representation and channel estimation for mmWave wideband massive MIMO systems. General mathematical channel models are proposed that explicitly consider various uncertainties in the systems, such as irregular array geometries and array disturbances. We then optimize the sparsifying dictionaries for efficient channel representation via dictionary learning concepts. Mathematical tools like compressive sensing were used to develop efficient and low overhead algorithms for channel estimation under different scenarios. 

In terms of broader impacts, the research provides a way for next generation cellular communication systems as well as local area networks, a means of exploiting higher bandwidths found at mmWave frequencies. Supporting data rates of tens of gigabits and beyond opens up many new applications of wireless communication to society. 

Results from the project were disseminated widely through publications in conferences, journals, and overview articles, with early access to such publications facilitated through preprint servers. Technology transfer was facilitated by incorporating material from the project into high visibility invited talks at conferences and companies, as well as in presentations to the Wireless Networking and Communications Group industrial affiliates, and internships by the graduate students working on the project.
